body: WHO is she, this Maggie Brown? we wondered, sitting shoulder to shoulder with strangers in her Clinton Hill restaurant, crunching into fried chicken served on floral porcelain. Judging by the textured chintz wallpaper and the crystal chandelier, she was not of this era. Someone remembered the unsinkable Molly, a k a Maggie, Brown. Another said she
title: $25 AND UNDER; International Grandma

body: WHEN Thomas Schutte took over as president of Pratt Institute in 1993, he said, one of the first things he discovered was the frustration that students felt about their adopted home. Sitting in Clinton Hill not far from where it meets Fort Greene, Pratt Institute, which was founded in 1887, was not exactly in Harvard Square. So Mr. Schutte took it
title: SQUARE FEET/Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn; Transforming an Unappealing Street

body: HAVING spent college summers in New York, Manu Sawkar knew that finding a more permanent place to live wouldn't be easy. One serendipitous summer, he rented a room from a man he met on a plane. One miserable summer, a Web listing led him to a tiny, noisy, overpriced room with a roommate who hated him. In the fall, finished with college and planning
title: THE HUNT; Three Guys and the 'Perfect-Tenant' Ideal

author: Nelly Rosario is the author of ''Song of the Water Saints,''a novel.
body: IF you applied today's world headlines to this microcosmic city, it would be easy to imagine a quilt torn to shreds. What exists, instead, is a city of complex fabrics: the Chinese in Little Italy, the Colombians in Jackson Heights. This is not to say ethnic conflicts don't exist on many levels here; polka dot and kente cloth do clash. But there's
title: THE NEXT WAVE; 'Sliding Up a Rabbit Hole Into Wonderland'

body: THE hallways are as dingy as can be, with yellow paint flaking onto beat-up tile floors. In the bare lobbies, elderly residents shuffle between elevators and front doors. Outside, cracked concrete paths wind among patches of lawn, the massive forms of the buildings hulking above. By all appearances this place -- the Cooperative Village, a
title: Incredible Hulks, Enticing the Young

body: While many New Yorkers might wonder about the fate of some candidates in today's election, Roger Green is not likely to be among them. title: In District Lines, Critics See Albany Protecting Its Own

body: Whose hands made this wall, the history books do not tell. Faceless lunch-pail carriers stacked these bricks and stones, men made briefly strong with twice-daily naval rations of grog, a roughly even mixture of water and rum. They are gone, but their wall remains, ambling around what were swamps and mud flats in their day, standing as their cairn
title: Peeking Over the Wall At the End of Brooklyn; The Navy Is Long Gone, but a Barrier Remains

title: THE HUNT; A Novice Learns the Hard Lessons Of Patience and Perseverance

body: ON a late August afternoon, the cream- and chocolate-colored facade of 401 Clinton Avenue in Brooklyn offered an elegant and impassive front, like a Southern lady of a certain age dozing on her front porch. With all her accessories perfectly preserved -- the opalescent stained glass made by a Tiffany competitor, John LaFarge; the turned wood spines
title: HABITATS/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; It All Started With the House

body: There are some good candidates running in this year's handful of contested races for New York City Civil Court. As usual, though, there is also a host of less promising contenders, at least some of whom are likely to win elevation to the bench in the low-visibility judicial races occurring this season in Brooklyn and the Bronx. That dismal prospect
title: For Civil Court

body: THE crucial decision this week is where to eat. Those who dare to set foot beyond the defensive perimeter of the convention site will find a city beckoning with more wonderful food of more varied types than just about anywhere else on earth. Let's start with a few New York staples, like the best pastrami sandwich. My favorite comes from Katz's
title: NEW YORK 2004: NEW YORK/DINING OUT; Beyond the Garden, Culinary Delights

body: THE sounds of renovation waft over the three broad, comfortable blocks of Clinton Avenue from Lafayette Avenue to Fulton Street in Brooklyn. title: STREETSCAPES/Clinton Avenue From Lafayette to Fulton, Brooklyn; In Clinton Hill, 3 Blocks Offer a Tour of 150 Years

body: With sunshine peeking through the clouds onto a crowded street festival at a Baptist church in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Roger L. Green worked the crowd in typical campaign mode. title: Workers Say Late Shifts Often Mean Locked Exits

title: Assemblyman's Resignation Puzzles Many in Brooklyn

title: Rheingold's Homecoming: Brewed Again in Brooklyn

title: Different by Design, Soon to Be Less So; Rethinking Atlantic Center With the Customer in Mind

body: ON fare-beating, the criminal cause and commercial activity around which his life found meaning, Alan Campbell speaks softly, almost monkishly. title: 1904-2004; Fare-Beater Inc.

body: Two gunmen opened fire at a Brooklyn nightclub early yesterday, wounding nine people, mostly in the legs and feet, the police said. The shooting occurred shortly before 3 a.m. at Cabaret Ovation, at 860 Atlantic Avenue in Clinton Hill, injuring seven men and two women, who ranged in age from 18 to 25, according to the police. All nine were treated
title: 9 Are Injured in Shooting at Brooklyn Club
